body.html:
Pursue your MFA in Writing

In Sarah Lawrence’s nationally recognized Masters in Writing program, students work in close collaboration with faculty members who are distinguished writers and devoted teachers.

MFA Creative Writing students choose to concentrate in these genres:

  • MFA Writing Fiction: 

    MFA Fiction students focus on bringing together precision of language with boldess of imaginative grasp. We closely study the craft lessons learned by the writers who have gone before us—but never lose sight of the fact that each new work of fiction is a leap into the unknown.

  • MFA Creative Nonfiction: 

    Our students engage in spirited and thought-provoking investigations of the aesthetics and ethics of nonfiction writing. MFA students consider questions such as: Is it possible to write freely about other people without exploiting them? Is there a difference between factual and essential truth? How do we find narrative coherence within the messy actualities of life?

  • MFA Poetry: 

    The focus is both minute and broad—examining poems on a cellular level, then talking about larger issues, such as poetic traditions and compositional techniques. We ask for full participation, deep inquiry, and rigor.

  • MFA Speculative Fiction: 

    We look closely at the special questions posed by speculative fiction, paying particular attention to the question of how to combine mind-bending world-building with powerful narrative drive. We begin from the premise that the literary exploration of alternative realities deserves as much respect as any other literary genre, and that fantasy and sci-fi writers are producing some of the most compelling fiction of our time.

During biweekly one-on-one conferences, our faculty engages with your work in depth and in detail, accompanying you every step of the way as you investigate the possibilities of your art. Masters of Creative Writing students enjoy the following benefits:

  • Each student is permitted to take classes in every genre we offer—fiction, poetry, nonfiction, and fantasy/sci-fi.
  • Students may study in the MFA Writing program either on a full- or part-time basis.
  • Study with award-winning faculty including Jo Ann Beard, Cathy Park Hong, Marie Howe, Mary Morris, Vijay Seshadri, and Joan Silber.
  • Benefit from our close proximity to New York City— just 30 minutes away from Midtown Manhattan.
  • A tradition of literary excellence for more than 80 years.

Join our literary community.

Learn More

Explore Dance Creatively, Conceptually, and Technically

Students in the MFA in Dance program are exposed to vital aspects of the art as performers, creators, and observers and are encouraged to study broadly, widen their definitions of dance and performance, and engage in explorations of form and function.

MFA in Dance Program highlights:

  • Combines seminars in reading, writing, and research; choreographic inquiry; and a daily physical practice chosen from various genres
  • All students study choreography, experiential anatomy, dance history, lighting design and stagecraft, and music for dancers
  • Students show original work each semester in the winter and spring concerts and present final projects in the MFA Dance concert in their last semester
  • Frequent guest artists and lecturers visit campus
  • Proximity to New York City's dance scene

body.html:
Listed among the Best College Theatre programs by The Princeton Review

The MFA Theatre is a two-year program that embraces an approach to theatre-making as progressive as the college itself and focuses on helping students locate themselves in the art form and find their individual aesthetic voice. Under the guidance of a faculty of artists who are working professionals, the program offers an advanced study of theatre that is multi-disciplinary, collaborative, extensive, and practical.

Multi-disciplinary

In contrast to programs which encourage specialization in theatre, the Sarah Lawrence MFA Theatre program emphasizes theatre- making as an integrative practice. Each student develops a program of study that draws from courses in acting, Alexander Technique, breathing, comedic and dramatic improvisation, creation of original work, design, directing, history, movement, playwriting, solo performance, puppetry, speech, voice, and the art of bringing theatre into the local community through Theatre Outreach. Our philosophy also encourages graduate students to enroll in classes in our music and dance departments as part of their program.

Collaborative

MFA Theatre students work closely in classes, conferences, and productions with the faculty, their fellow graduate students, and the College’s undergraduate theatre community.

Extensive

The emphasis of the MFA Theatre program is on the development of original work, grounded in a study of classical and contemporary forms and in a variety of performance styles.

Practical

Graduate curricular work is augmented by a practicum in which students learn by doing. There are multiple production venues available to MFA Theatre students that offer a wide range of practical opportunities in acting, singing, dance, design, directing, ensemble creation, playwriting, and technical work. Our Outreach program also provides students with teaching placements in elementary schools, colleges, senior centers, half-way houses, and prisons, to name a few. Students may also participate in internships or fieldwork in New York City theatres and theatre organizations.

Interested? Take the next step.

body.html:
HELPING WRITERS BECOME
THE WRITERS THEY WANT TO BE

  • Year-Round Start Dates: From writing conferences to one-day writing seminars to 11-week writing and publishing workshops—The Writing Institute has something for everyone!
  • Award-Winning Faculty: Work with published writers and other experts at the SLC Writing Institute.
  • On Campus or Online: classes in fiction, non-fiction, and publishing are also offered online

WRITERS WORKSHOPS

  • Fiction Writing Workshops: We help students at all levels of experience move ahead in their writing.
  • Nonfiction Writing Workshops: Our small classes (12 or fewer students) allow for constructive, supportive, challenging responses to student writing.

  • Online Writing Workshops: Write from the comfort of your home or wherever you may travel with our Online Writing Workshops that include explorations into writing fiction, memoir, editing, and classes on how to get published, among others.  

  • Certificate in Book Publishing: a new program starting in June, 2018. If your goal is to launch a career in publishing as an editor, literary agent, or publicist; or if you dream of publishing your own book one day, this is your chance to get an insider's look deep into this fascinating industry.
  • Publishing Workshops: Looking to publish and promote your book? We offer a variety of classes throughout the year as well as our annual Publish and Promote Your Book event on June 23, 2018; a unique one-day conference that will help you connect with New York City literary agents, meet with major publishing house editors, pitch your book to agents and editors, and more!
  • What Genre or Genres Do You Find Most Enticing? The Writing institute offers workshops in self-publishing, narrative, personal essay, short story, novel writing, poetry, memoir, magazine writing, screenwriting, writing for television and film, writing for young adult, and social media for writers.

Join our community of writers!

Learn More

body.html:
Master’s in Health Advocacy

Students pursue an MA in Health Advocacy at Sarah Lawrence College because they want to solve problems.

Some work in and with local communities to affect change. Others help individuals navigate an increasingly complex health care system. Still others work to influence policy to make government and industry more accountable for actions that jeopardize the health of our communities.

The Health Advocacy program at Sarah Lawrence College offers:

  • An 18-month, low residency format that leads to a Master of Arts degree and prepares professionals to solve problems affecting individual and community health
  • An opportunity to work with expert faculty in a multi-disciplinary course of study
  • Experience developing a program to address your area of focus with a partner organization of your choosing
What problem do you want to solve?

body.html:
Study Abroad in Florence, Italy with Sarah Lawrence College

Sarah Lawrence College offers what is arguably the most genuine experience of living and learning in Florence, Italy. We welcome both study abroad students who have little to no experience with the language as well as students who have advanced study in Italian. 

Students may study history, social sciences or take part in our distinguished studio arts art restoration and music programs. Students also have the opportunity to participate in internships during the semester. Placements include working with children in local schools, serving as international tour guides at cultural sites, and special internships at museum collections throughout Italy.

All Sarah Lawrence Florence study abroad students participate in small seminars with Italian faculty and work one-on-one with their faculty in individual tutorials - a hallmark of the distinctive Sarah Lawrence pedgogy. Students may work with creative artists in their studios, study music in Florentine conservatories, or learn alongside Italian students at the University of Florence. For a truly authentic and immersive experience, all students live with Italian families. This combination of living and learning leads to connections with the vibrant Florentine community and culture that last a lifetime.

Terms: Fall, Spring, Academic Year, Summer

Credits: 15 per semester; 6 credits in the Summer

Housing: Homestay

Language of Instruction: No previous study in Italian required.

Average Program Size: 20

Study Abroad in Florence, Italy: Program Highlights

  • Small seminars
  • One-on-one meetings with professors
  • Specialized programs in: 
– Anthropology
– Art History
– Art Restoration
– History
– Italian Language
– Music
– Politics
– Studio Art
  • Internships

Want to know more? Ready to apply? Please use the contact form on this page to take the next step on your journey to Florence with Sarah Lawrence College!

body.html:
Study Abroad in Paris, France with Sarah Lawrence College

Sarah Lawrence welcomes undergraduate students from any college or university to join the distinguished Sarah Lawrence College Study Abroad Program in Paris.

For more than 60 years, Sarah Lawrence College has offered unique opportunities for undergraduate study abroad. The legendary hallmarks of a Sarah Lawrence education—small classes and one-on-one meetings with faculty—are what set our programs around the world apart. Undergraduate students from Sarah Lawrence and other selective colleges study side by side during a rigorous and life-changng semester or year abroad.

In Paris, Sarah Lawrence will give you the opportunity and the means to experience the creative and intellectual traditions that have made the city a destination for writers, artists, and philosophers since medieval times. The Paris study abroad program enables you to craft a personalized and intellectually stimulating course of study, while providing you with the opportunity to take advantage of Paris’ rich cultural life.

Terms: Fall, Spring, Academic Year

Credits: 15 per semester

Housing: Homestay, International Student Dorms, Apartments

Language of Instruction: French and English; two program tracks accommodate students at various levels of fluency

Average Program Size: 22

Unique Features:

  • Small seminars
  • One-on-one meetings with professors
  • Intensive programs are available in the visual arts and the social sciences
  • Opportunity to study at French universities and in various studios and conservatories in and around Paris

Want to know more? Ready to apply? Please use the contact form on this page to take the next step on your journey to Paris with Sarah Lawrence College!

body.html:
Study the Arts Abroad in Florence with Sarah Lawrence College

Working directly with distinguished Florentine artists in studio and conservatory settings, students studying the arts in Sarah Lawrence College's study abroad in Florence program expand their knowledge and expertise through a combination of research, technical training and creative projects. Visits to libraries, museums and private collections enhance this work.

Florence Arts Course Offerings

Study Abroad in Florence: Art Restoration - Diane Kunzelman

The Art Restoration study abroad course is designed for students with a background in Art History (at least one college year) and is taught both at the program palazzo and at one of the main restoration labs in Florence. The course offers a solid understanding of the artistic techniques typical of the Tuscan-Florentine ambience, particularly for the period from the 14th century through the Renaissance: physical and chemical composition of objects relative to each of the techniques treated, the historical evolution and development of these techniques, their conservation and restoration, including scientific methods of diagnosis and examination of works of art. This study abroad course concentrates on painting: fresco and other types of wall painting, painting on wood panel and on canvas.

Lessons in the studio will involve each of the students in a personal project, through the realization of a simple example derived from a l4th/l5th century original, for each of the basic techniques treated. The purpose of this project is to familiarize the student with the structure and material composition of the works of art, fundamental for the comprehension of phenomena of deterioration and damage and subsequent restoration. The course includes visits to art exhibits in and around Florence.

Study Abroad in Florence: Art on Paper - Swietlan Nicholas Kraczyna

A study abroad art course specially designed for students with an interest in art, drawing, painting, and etching/print-making. Studio time and site visits offer opportunities to explore different facets of the visual arts such as still-life, figure-drawing, and self-portrait. One-on-one sessions with the instructor help students monitor personal growth and develop strength. Students keep a sketchbook with daily entries and work on more detailed and specific projects in the studio. During the second semester focus shifts to print-making and etching. All students will present an individual project to be displayed at the annual exhibition.

Study Abroad in Florence: Photography - Baerbel Reinhard

Taught exclusively at the Marangoni studios in Florence, students who study abroad in this photography course are provided the opportunity to experiment with different photographic techniques and ultimately lead them to define their own approach within the contemporary photographic movement. Students explore different possibilities in photography through various assignments that include focusing on interiors, portraits, street photography, urban and social landscape, self-portrait, natural landscape, and staged photography. Issues involving image production, techniques, and expressive languages will be explored by studying the History of Photography and the works of master photographers.

Study Abroad in Florence: Music - Kamran Khacheh (Music Theory)

Qualified study abroad students with a background in music may elect to study music as one third of their program. This highly regarded study abroad music program offers conservatory study at all levels. Music students take private lessons in voice or an instrument and study solfege, theory and composition at the center, the Scuola di Musica di Fiesole, the Scuola di Musica di Sesto Fiorentino (classical) or the Centro Attività Musicali (CAM) for jazz and electronic music. Students may also join a performance group.

body.html:
Study Theatre Abroad in Paris with Sarah Lawrence College

Paris’ cultural history, rich in the Pierrot, mask and mime traditions, provides an ideal context for the pursuit of theatrical experimentation.

In general, theatre study abroad students in the Paris program may choose one 4 credit course per semester. A typical theater course consists of three components:

  • Theory or History
  • Acting Instruction
  • Movement or Voice

Students specializing in theater may consider applying to the Sarah Lawrence Study Abroad in Paris intensive program. All classes are conducted exclusively in French. The study abroad theater program in Paris centers around the following institutions:

Atelier de Belleville

  • Dramatic corporal mime following the method of Etienne Decroux
  • Analysis of the importance of silence for the modern man, whose actions are no longer connected to economic production
  • Study and analysis of essential aspects of human drama: passions, dreams, etc.

La Compagnie Nomad

  • Textual and Gestual Theater
  • Preparation of the body for maximum awareness: sensorial awakening through the exploration of the inner space
  • Yawning and soft vibration of vocal cords
  • Consciousness of space and others onstage
  • Exploration of the self and the other designed to build the actor’s autonomy

Le Samovar

  • The clown: analysis and in-depth study of clown acting
  • Improvisation around a given theme: daily life, relationship to objects, singing, writing for clowns
  • Clowns and body language: grounding the body in the real, masks, the silence of the clown

Studio Alain de Bock

  • Courses in improvisation, interpretation, clown and commedia dell’arte
  • Musical theater workshops
  • Acting for the camera, experimenting with stage directors
  • All major pedagogical schools are taught: classical, Stanislavian, Italian, Brechtian, etc.
  • Physical training is an integral part of the classes

body.html:
Study Dance Abroad in Paris with Sarah Lawrence College

The Sarah Lawrence study abroad in Paris dance program offers an introduction to the world of dance abroad and is designed to give students a European dance and cultural experience. The program offers an overview of the major choreographic and technical influences in European countries during the last century, a wide choice of movement practices with various teachers, and the possibility to attend performances featuring contemporary European choreographers.

In general, students may choose one 4 credit course per semester.

A typical study abroad dance course at Sarah Lawrence consists of three components:

  1. A Theoretical Component
    a. History of European Dance in the 20th Century (1st semester)
    b. Anatomy and Kinesiology (2nd semester)
  2. Improvisation and Composition
  3. Three Dance Classes
    a. Modern dance
    b. Two electives (African dance, ballet, flamenco, tap, etc.)

Advanced students who wish to concentrate over half of their coursework in dance may consider applying to the 8 credit intensive program. In addition to the regular dance curriculum, students in the intensive program enroll in an extra elective and in intensive workshops at institutions such as the Menagerie de Verre a multidisciplinary studio dedicated to contemporary creation that regularly welcomes choreographers, performers, filmmakers and visual artists.

Want to know more? Ready to apply? Please use the contact form on this page to take the next step on your journey to Paris with Sarah Lawrence College!

body.html:
Pursue your MFA Writing Creative Nonfiction

In Sarah Lawrence’s nationally recognized MFA Creative Nonfiction program, students work in close collaboration with faculty members who are active, successful writers.

Our MFA Creative Nonfiction students engage in spirited and thought-provoking investigations of the aesthetics and ethics of nonfiction writing. MFA students consider questions such as: Is it possible to write about other people without exploiting them? Is there a difference between factual and essential truth? How do we find narrative coherence within the messy actualities of life?

During biweekly one-on-one conferences, our faculty of distinguished writers engage with your work in depth and in detail, accompanying your every step of the way as you investigate the possibilities of your art.

Students may study in the MFA Writing Creative Nonfiction program either on a full- or part-time basis.

  • Study with award-winning faculty including Jo Ann Beard, Marie Howe, Mary Morris, Vijay Seshadri, and Joan Silber.
  • Benefit from our close proximity to New York City— just 30 minutes away from Midtown Manhattan.
  • A tradition of literary excellence for more than 80 years.

Join our distinguished literary community.

body.html:
Master of Arts Degree in Women's History

The program immerses students in a combination of historical studies, feminist theory, and gender studies. It also draws extensively upon resources in the social sciences and literature, and on a legacy of continuing activism both within and outside the College community.

An accelerated degree option for students especially concerned with practical applications of historical knowledge to issues of gender policy and advocacy allows students to earn their MA in Women’s History in 15 months of continuous study.

Notable facts about the program:

  • Founded in 1972, Sarah Lawrence’s MA in Women’s History was the first to offer a graduate degree in the field.

  • The Women’s History faculty is enriched by professors from other fields, including literature;anthropology; Africana studies; sociology; economics; Asian studies; art history; psychology; lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender studies; and more.

  • A joint degree in Women’s History and Law is offered in cooperation with Pace University Law School. Students in this program earn both a Master of Arts and a Juris Doctor.

  • The annual Women’s History Month Conference is held the first weekend of March.

  • School term internships may be chosen by students as an option for fulfilling their elective requirements.

 

“This program has a long history of intellectual rigor ... and also a long history of social activism. And Sarah Lawrence is an ideal place to learn. The graduate students have access to absolutely wonderful mentors.”— Mary Reynolds, Organizer, Unite Here

 

Join our community!

body.html:
Study Abroad in Havana, Cuba with Sarah Lawrence College

Cuba’s influence on culture and politics has intrigued the world for many years. Yet, until very recently, this island nation had been off-limits to most Americans for two generations. Sarah Lawrence’s Study Abroad program in Havana has, since its beginning, aimed to expose American students to a culturally and politically unique society about which much has been written, but little is widely known.

From the program’s beginning, its mission has been to expose students at American universities to a culturally and politically unique society about which much has been written, but of which far less is widely known. As the longest continuously running study abroad program in Havana, it offers a small and intimate classroom experience as well as a full Spanish language immersion. These experiences promise a sense of authenticity influenced by Sarah Lawrence traditions and ideals.

The wealth of an education can be calculated by measuring the diversity of its parts. So the value of this Sarah Lawrence program can be found in the wide, creative range of the classes, seminars, fieldwork and site visits offered to its students. Enrollment is kept small intentionally so that faculty can devote individual attention to each student.

Terms: Fall and Spring

Credits: 15 per semester

Housing: All students live together in ANAP, a residence (casa de visita) belonging to the National Small Farmer’s Association (Asociación Nacional de Agricultores Pequeños). It’s centrally located in Vedado, one of Havana’s residential neighborhoods. Students can conveniently walk to the University of Havana, the Malecón and many cultural venues.

Language of Instruction: Spanish

Average Program Size: 12 to 15 students

Study Abroad in Havana, Cuba: Program Highlights

  • Small seminars
  • One-on-one meetings with professors
  • Study Abroad in Havana, Cuba concentrations include:
    • Social Sciences
    • Humanities
    • the Arts

Want to know more? Ready to apply? Please use the contact form on this page to take the next step on your journey to Havana with Sarah Lawrence College!

Sarah Lawrence College in Havana

The Sarah Lawrence College in Havana program is highly selective and is open to juniors and seniors enrolled at any accredited American college or university. Students may apply for application in either the fall or spring. Each student takes four courses for a total of 15 credits. Course work includes Spanish at an advanced level, one core seminar on Cuban society and development, and electives in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts. From the beginning, the program's mission has been to expose American students to a culturally and politically unique society about which much has been written, but of which far less is widely known.

body.html:
Study Abroad in Beijing, China with Sarah Lawrence College

Sarah Lawrence College in Beijing is a new program offered in conjunction with the Alliance for Global Education. It is designed for students who have completed a minimum of one year of Chinese (Mandarin) at the college level, and wish to continue their studies in this major Chinese city. During this program, students will be immersed in Chinese language and customs while learning about contemporary culture through the arts, media and sociopolitical lenses. In addition to enrolling in a language course, a core course and electives, students may participate in an internship that will solidify the immersion experience. Students live with local families to allow for greater integration and a more gain an authentic experience of Chinese culture and improve their language skills.

Terms: Fall, Spring or Full-Year

Credits: 15 per semester

Housing: Students will spend the first two weeks of the semester in university housing, which will allow students to complete orientation together and become acquainted with their surroundings. After the initial two weeks, students will move into homestays.

Language of Instruction: English and Mandarin

Average Program Size:  12 to 15 students

Study Abroad in Beijing, China: Program Highlights

  • Small seminars
  • One-on-one meetings with professors
  • Courses include:

- Chinese language

- Core course in which students become familiar with China’s culture, philosophy, historical and social development

- Electives in foreign policy, filmmaking, visual arts

- Internships for credit

Want to know more? Ready to apply? Please use the contact form on this page to take the next step on your journey to Beijing with Sarah Lawrence College!

body.html:
Where will your academic journey take you?  

Rigorous. Rewarding.

At Sarah Lawrence you’ll work hard. But your work will be your work. You'll create a course of study that is uniquely yours—a path you’re eager to pursue each day.

With hundreds of courses in nearly 50 disciplines, we offer a remarkable depth and breadth of academic opportunity. You could explore the conflicts in the Middle East by delving into the art of the region, merge game design and sociology to create a new interactive paradigm, or take on pre-law in parallel with a close look at the English Romantic poets. 

Across all your endeavors at Sarah Lawrence, you'll ask important questions, challenge assumptions, gain greater knowledge of the world and your place in it, and develop the critical thinking and problem-solving skills that will be vitally important in both your career and your life.

Come join an extraordinary community: generations of passionate, intellectual, creative graduates who have called Sarah Lawrence College home.

body.html:
Planning for Summer 2018 at Sarah Lawrence College is Happening now!

  • High School Summer Writing Workshop: this 1-weeklong workshop offers writers (grades 9–12) an opportunity to explore the creative process with skilled writers and artists, and to experience the joys of writing in a supportive environment.
  • Summer Film Intensive: run in collaboration with the International Film Institute of New York, this 5-week program offers students of all ages hands-on experience in writing, directing, production, and post-production.
  • Writer's Village: this 3-week intensive immerses students (age 14+) in the craft of writing through workshops, readings, craft talks, and free writing exercises.
  • Summer Seminar for Writers: a 1-weeklong seminar for adult writers (21+) to experience the Sarah Lawrence pedagogy, work with faculty, and to spend a week in a stimulating, supportive writing atmosphere.
  • Pre-College Social Justice Workshop: an immersion for high school students into the world of social justice activism. Students will get an opportunity to learn about and perform activism through social media, visual art, performance, creative writing. The examination of current events will provide opportunity to dialog around diversity, race, gender and other issues through an intersectional lens.

To learn more about programs like these and to be among the first to know what we're planning for Summer 2018, join our mailing list today!

body.html:
Introducing Sarah Lawrence Giving Day

Giving Day is April 4, 2016, a day when Sarah Lawrence College alumni, students, parents, friends, faculty, and staff come together for Sarah Lawrence. We depend on your generous, ongoing support to keep Sarah Lawrence relevant, rewarding, and ahead of the curve.

What Makes This One Day So Special?

We have several donors who have jointly pledged a $100,000 fund to match every new gift we receive on that day until their funds run out. For this one day, Sarah Lawrence community members can show their support in a particularly powerful way, with each dollar donated being doubled. Every matched dollar means twice the resources for our students, for our faculty, for Sarah Lawrence. Please join us.

Giving Day Event Details

Date

April 4, 2016

Time

12:00 a.m.–11:59 p.m.

Where

Here at http://www.sarahlawrence.edu/givingday

Why

For our students, for our faculty, for our campus, for our future, for Sarah Lawrence

Why This Day

We have several donors willing to match funds on 4/4, up to a total of $100,000!

How

Mark your calendar for April 4.
Then, give online at http://alum.slc.edu/givetoday

Why Give to Sarah Lawrence?

Contributions to The Fund for Sarah Lawrence help bridge the gap between tuition revenue and the cost of delivering a Sarah Lawrence education. They help support the College’s outstanding faculty and enable the College to embark on new initiatives. They further the technological needs of faculty and students, and help preserve and enhance the historic campus.

Your gift, combined with many others, really makes a difference for our students, for our academic programs, for Sarah Lawrence. Participation matters! High participation rates will encourage similar matches in the future, and let the world know that our alumni, parents, and friends stand proud for Sarah Lawrence.

Contact The Fund for Sarah Lawrence

Questions about Giving Day? Need more information on how you can help? Reach out to us at annual@sarahlawrence.edu or you can call the office at (914) 813-9220.

We Need Your Help! Sign up to Volunteer.

We need your help getting the word out! We would love for you to like our Facebook pages, follow us on Twitter, and then share information about Giving Day and your Sarah Lawrence experience on social media. Fill out the form and find out more information on volunteering.

We need you to get the word out. Be a Social Media Ambassador! Please share on Facebook, Twitter, and elsewhere. We would love to hear your authentic voice, but here are some suggestions to get you started if you're searching for the right thing to say.

Contact The Fund for Sarah Lawrence

Questions about Giving Day? Need more information on how you can help? Reach out to us at annual@sarahlawrence.edu or you can call the office at (914) 813-9220.

Please Help Sarah Lawrence on Giving Day, 4/4, a Day to Double Gifts

On April 4 only, members of the Sarah Lawrence community will come together for a 24 hour fundraising challenge. All gifts, up to a combined total of $125,000, will be matched. On this special day, your donations to Sarah Lawrence will go twice as far.

We need your enthusiasm for the day to be a success! Share your support for the day on social media. Post and let people know why you choose to give or about the community you found here at Sarah Lawrence. Tag your posts with our event hashtag: #all4SarahLawrence. You can powerfully affect the outcome of this day just with your enthusiasm, especially on social media.

How You Can Help 

  • Please spread the word about this event! (Sure, we would love for you to go on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and more –- and there are resources below for you to do just that, but we also just want you to talk about Giving Day with your friends. Get the word out!)

  • Please rally your friends to give on April 4. This day offers the unique opportunity for every gift to go further. Participation matters! Last year's high participation encouraged this year's matches.

  • Use the following hashtag when you share on social media: #all4SarahLawrence.

  • Please like The Fund for Sarah Lawrence’s Facebook page. 

  •  Follow SLC Alumni on Twitter. 

  • Share your Sarah Lawrence story on social media. Tell your friends what you came to Sarah Lawrence for. Tell them what you give for.

  • Finally, mark your calendar and make a gift on 4/4. Do so early in the day to encourage others!

body.html:
MAYAPPLE AND SARAH LAWRENCE COLLEGE SUMMER INTENSIVE

The Art of Losing: Writing Against Disaster

Sunday, June 12 – Sunday, June 19, 2016

Sarah Lawrence College has embarked on an innovative partnership with Mayapple Center for the Arts and Humanities to offer summer programs in the arts and humanities that address contemporary issues within global society. This summer's program is a one-week creative writing intensive for adults centered around the theme The Art of Losing: Writing Against Disaster.

The act of writing is an attempt to recognize the world, especially as it becomes increasingly unrecognizable. This workshop treats the writer's work as a citizen of this world: one that can either suffer from reading the daily news or evoke memories and invent visions of the future. If one's writing is to survive, it must speak back to it, without creating forcibly political overtones. If one's writing is to help the world survive, it must be as precise and individual as one's own experiences.

While writing is often defined as a solitary act, art, like living, thrives on connection and collaboration. Together, we will explore what it means to communicate the complicated experience that is being alive today.

The Mayapple & Sarah Lawrence College Summer Intensive provides a welcoming environment where writers can truly focus on their writing. Participants are encouraged to take creative and intellectual risks and to cross disciplinary boundaries. The workshop is capped at fifteen writers, ensuring that each individual will be heard. Following the daily workshop, participants will have the opportunity to work one-on-one with the instructor. Participants will share their final projects in a reading as a culmination of the workshop.

QUESTIONS? Call us at (914) 395-2371.

body.html:
Wujing Wang ’16: For me, art is the presentation of an idea. I once read a book written by Paul Graham [called Hackers & Painters: Big Ideas from the Computer Age]. He is a big hacker and also learned painting at RISD. He feels like programming is also art, and for him it’s the same as painting because you have an idea of what you want to do; you write some code, you add some code, you debug—and for painting, you have a sketch, you add more lines, you erase, and you add more lines, and you edit it. With games … you can choose the different design, story lines, different graphic designs, and also different music. For me, I think games are art.

Omar Noel ’13: In that sense, any game with a story can be seen as a work of art.

Wujing Wang ’16: But it doesn’t have to be a story. Even just graphics.

Omar Noel ’13: But those graphics come along with a story.

Ian Reddick ’13: For one of my other classes this week, I had to define art and entertainment. I decided that art is an abstraction on the world—you’ve heard the phrase “art imitates life”—and then entertainment is meant to be a diversion. Entertainment can take on a lot of the same forms as art—like movies, for instance—but it doesn’t have any obligation to be as good as art … At least in the earliest days of making video games, I don’t think video games were intended as art. I think they were intended as entertainment, and today there’s more of a blurry line between the two of them …

William Bellamy ’13: I think it’s safe to say, though, that when [the Founding Fathers] thought they were representing the true spirit of the American Revolution, they had a unique perspective on the matter that was conditioned or structured by slavery. That’s an interesting irony … what creates their notion of democracy (or at least republicanism) stems from the most fundamentally anti-democratic institution in the nation’s history.

Eileen Cheng: But again, to their minds, it wasn’t anti-democratic to believe in slavery; for them slaves weren’t people, and to enslave wasn’t necessarily to violate the ideals expressed in the Declaration of Independence.

Cameron Saunders ’13: Can we say then that the Confederacy saw the powers of the Union and of Congress [infringing on states’ rights] as the equivalent of the British Parliament taxing [the colonies]?

Eileen Cheng: Well, there you see very strongly the Confederate link to the Revolutionaries. They aren’t imposing tyranny—the North is. And they may have a point. They can point to the three-fifths clause in the Constitution. The Founding Fathers were okay with having slavery be a part of the Republic … But there’s something incredibly self-destructive about what they decide to do. Secede. Fight the Civil War despite being at a huge disadvantage in terms of industrial might and sheer numbers. Why would they go to war?

Isaac Krasny ’11: Well, look at the decision they were making: should they put up with conditions they objected to or should they declare independence and potentially have to defend themselves? It was the exact decision the revolutionaries had to make. They went to war against the most powerful empire in the world, knowing their chances of success were very slim. The Confederacy was facing similar odds, but they were driven by ideology, not practicality. They were asking themselves, “How do we best preserve the rights given to us by the founders?”

body.value: Loading...

body.html:
Matthew Ellis: So how do you do business in the Sahara Desert? This is a great expanse, and we’re talking about long-distance trade, not local trade … Caravan trips could be as long as 70 days. These were serious distances that were being traversed. Let’s not take for granted that you can just do business with anyone.

Maya Ahmed ’17: Gold was a very important commodity, and that’s what they all desire and seek …

Matthew Ellis: So a certain commodity that everyone can agree on—that’s a common denominator. What else?

Christina Tang ’17: Religion can be used for trade so that people trust each other more.

Allison Snyder ’17: It’s sort of like an honor code.

Matthew Ellis: Exactly! When you think about the word “bonds,” when you’re actually writing bonds or deeds, the fact that there was a common language of religion to undergird it was really significant. I think you guys are really right on here. Islam became the language of commerce … What we have going on in the Sahara are lots of different kinds of people with different languages—all these different tribes from east and west Africa, Muslim merchants from the Mediterranean, from Egypt. Do they necessarily speak the same language?

Class: No

Matthew Ellis: So what they share is religion.

Priscilla Liu ’14: We use this image of the Other to make our lives more bearable. Listening to these stories is crippling. People do not want to hear these stories … I think this is linked to our reading, which shows that some people blame the new migrants for the declining influence of unions. But that has nothing to do with it! We should be addressing the economics first.

Daisy Hill ’14: I think people are afraid to see and understand what’s really happening here.

Jaimie Luria ’12: It’s all unbelievably ironic. There’s this idea of “othering,” but these people—these actual human beings—are so integrated into our society …they’re a huge part of the structure of our daily lives. There’s no way to reconcile the idea that the busboy is an “alien” with the idea that it’s fine for him to clean your dishes.

Aman Banerji ’14: Sociologically, it’s just easy for people to make this divide. We want the chance to say, “They’re not like us; we don’t need to understand them.”

Shura Wallin: (referring back to Daisy Hill) The media keeps this fear going. They seem to say “if only”—if only we could purge the United States of everyone who is not “us,” then everything would be fine. They simplify a very complicated issue. Our policy is this: we don’t want you, but we want your labor.

Patrisia Macias: I’m really hearing two questions here. The one that Jaimie opened up with is “Why is this allowed to happen?” And we’re trying to work through some of the explanations. But Kayla asked a provocative question that I think we should address. In terms of responding to the racial hierarchy, she suggests it’s a by-product of economic conditions. That’s a controversial claim. Many would say, “Hell no, this is all about racism.”

body.html:
The International Film Institute Summer intensive

As part of a long-running partnership, Sarah Lawrence College and the International Film Institute of New York (IFI) are happy to offer you a unique opportunity to learn the art of filmmaking in an in-depth, supportive, and intimate summer film program.

Gain hands-on experience and instruction in all aspects of filmmaking, focusing on four core elements:

  • Writing for the screen
  • Directing
  • Production
  • Post-production

Lectures feature hands-on camera work, augmented by special guest speakers and behind-the-scenes visits to Manhattan production studios and editing facilities. After you shoot three film exercises focused on different filmmaking techniques, you’re ready to write, direct, produce, shoot, and edit your own short video. You choose the format: narrative, documentary, or experimental. You may choose to stick to a script with actors, costumes, and a controlled set, or you may approach your shoot with the spirit of improvisation. The final product is your completed short—to which you own the exclusive rights—ready for your professional portfolio, graduate school application, or Web distribution. 

READY to Learn More about the Summer Film Program?

Not only was I able to listen to and learn from top agents, editors and publicists during the panel portion of the conference, I was also able to connect with them directly during the one-on-one pitch sessions...It was at the conference that I was lucky enough to meet my agent who recently sold my first novel.”

Lynda Loigman, author of The Two Family House, St. Martin's Pres, 2016

Thank you for your interest in the Publish & Promote Conference with the Writing Institute at Sarah Lawrence College!

The 4th Annual Publish & Promote Conference is a one-day conference designed to help you succeed in your publishing ventures. The conference brings together writers, editors, agents, and publishers to network and learn more about the publishing industry.

About The Writing Institute

When we were founded over 30 years ago, we put out a call for adults interested in writing. Since then, we've gone from offering three courses (in fiction or expository writing) to offering dozens each semester, plus one-day intensives, publishing conferences, and writer reading nights! If you're interested in moving further in your writing, we're here for you. Each of our workshops is small (capped at 12 students) and designed to facilitate a collegial community of writers. Whether you're interested in fiction, non-fiction, poetry, a class for your young writer or something else altogether, we've got the class for you! Check out our current offering and peruse our workshops here.

We look forward to meeting you in one of our classes or at one of our upcoming events. If you have any questions, please feel free to email ( cce@sarahlawrence.edu ) or call us at (914) 395-2205.

body.html:
Spread the Love!

88 years ago (October 4, 1928 to be exact), Sarah Lawrence College welcomed its first students to campus for a uniquely driven education. From there, the Sarah Lawrence spirit has spread across the globe. Let’s keep it going! Join us to spread the love and celebrate the last 88 years – share pics of your Sarah Lawrence swag! Drinking coffee in a Sarah Lawrence mug? Watching your favorite TV shows in a Sarah Lawrence sweatshirt? Sleeping with a stuffed black squirrel? Snap a pic, hashtag it #ilovesarahlawrence, and share it on social media. Our goal is to get 88 posts every day during the week of October 3-9; see the latest below!

Join Us on Social Media

Want to connect with students, faculty, and staff from Sarah Lawrence College? Check out our social media dashboard to find us on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Tumblr, YouTube, and more.

body.html:
Dignity in Health Care at All Ages and Stages of Life

Sarah Lawrence College’s End-of-Life Care program aims to create a new culture of medical care around end-of-life issues. The program addresses the growing need for information, tools, and analysis on topics such as palliative care and advance care planning, as they relate to patients, health care professionals, caregivers, and the general public.

Advance Care Planning for Primary Care Practitioners (ACP4PCP) is a non-credit, 4 hour CME, CEU certificate in advance care planning for practitioners and practices that receive Medicare B reimbursement. Continuing education units are sponsored through joint providership with National Hospice and Palliative Care Organization.

ACP4PCP offers an introduction to the basic knowledge and skills of advance care planning in three 1-hour online, self-paced courses:

  • COURSE 1: Foundations of Advance Care Planning (1.5 CMEs/CE's)
  • COURSE 2: The Advance Care Planning Conversation (1.5 CMEs/CE's)
  • COURSE 3: Complexities of Advance Care Planning (1 CMEs/CE's)

Completion of the Advance Care Planning for Primary Care Practitioners Certificate equips health care practitioners with the basic knowledge and skills to successfully address your patients’ advance care planning needs.

These courses offered in joint providership with
National Hospice and Palliative Care Organization.

body.html:
The International Film Institute Summer intensive

As part of a long-running partnership, Sarah Lawrence College and the International Film Institute of New York (IFI) are happy to offer you a unique opportunity to learn the art of filmmaking in an in-depth, supportive, and intimate summer film program.

Gain hands-on experience and instruction in all aspects of filmmaking, focusing on four core elements:

  • Writing for the screen
  • Directing
  • Production
  • Post-production

Lectures feature hands-on camera work, augmented by special guest speakers and behind-the-scenes visits to Manhattan production studios and editing facilities. After you shoot three film exercises focused on different filmmaking techniques, you’re ready to write, direct, produce, shoot, and edit your own short video. You choose the format: narrative, documentary, or experimental. You may choose to stick to a script with actors, costumes, and a controlled set, or you may approach your shoot with the spirit of improvisation. The final product is your completed short—to which you own the exclusive rights—ready for your professional portfolio, graduate school application, or Web distribution. 

READY to Learn More about the Summer Film Program?

body.html:
Planning for Summer 2017 at Sarah Lawrence College is Happening now!

  • High School Summer Writing Workshop: this 1-weeklong workshop offers writers (grades 9–12) an opportunity to explore the creative process with skilled writers and artists, and to experience the joys of writing in a supportive environment.
  • Summer Film Intensive: run in collaboration with the International Film Institute of New York, this 5-week program offers students of all ages hands-on experience in writing, directing, production, and post-production.
  • Writer's Village: this 3-week intensive immerses students (age 14+) in the craft of writing through workshops, readings, craft talks, and free writing exercises.
  • Summer Seminar for Writers: a 1-weeklong seminar for adult writers (21+) to experience the Sarah Lawrence pedagogy, work with faculty, and to spend a week in a stimulating, supportive writing atmosphere.
  • Pre-College Social Justice Workshop: an immersion for high school students into the world of social justice activism. Students will get an opportunity to learn about and perform activism through social media, visual art, performance, creative writing. The examination of current events will provide opportunity to dialog around diversity, race, gender and other issues through an intersectional lens.

To learn more about programs like these and to be among the first to know what we're planning for Summer 2017, join our mailing list today!

body.html:
Master’s in Health Advocacy

Students pursue an MA in Health Advocacy at Sarah Lawrence College because they want to solve problems.

Some work in and with local communities to affect change. Others help individuals navigate an increasingly complex health care system. Still others work to influence policy to make government and industry more accountable for actions that jeopardize the health of our communities.

The Health Advocacy program at Sarah Lawrence College offers:

  • An 18-month, low residency format that leads to a Master of Arts degree and prepares professionals to solve problems affecting individual and community health
  • An opportunity to work with expert faculty in a multi-disciplinary course of study
  • Experience developing a program to address your area of focus with a partner organization of your choosing
What problem do you want to solve?

body.html:
Graduate Studies at Sarah Lawrence College

Sarah Lawrence College offers nine distinctive master's degree programs in the arts, humanities, and sciences, and three unique dual degrees.

Our graduate-level programs include:

  • Master of Fine Arts (MFA) programs in Dance, Theatre, and Writing
  • Master of Science (MS) programs in Art of Teaching, Dance/Movement Therapy, and Human Genetics
  • Master of Arts (MA) programs in Child Development, Health Advocacy, and Women’s History. Students in the Child Development program may pursue a dual master's degree (MA/MSW) with the NYU Silver School of Social Work. The Women’s History program partners with Pace Law School to offer a joint degree.

As a Sarah Lawrence graduate degree student, you will find your academic home—a community comprised of vibrant thinkers and doers; a solid framework for your most complex ideas, interests, and investigations; and, perhaps most significantly, encouragement for deep specialization in a course of study that is uniquely yours.

Interested? Take the next step.

Information: Advance Care Planning Certificate

Get the Training You Need and Provide the Person-Centered Care You Envision for your Patients!

Sign up to view the video and learn more about Advance Care Planning for Primary Care Practitioners.

Did you know…

10,000 people a day are becoming eligible for Medicare and all of these people need Advance Care Planning (ACP) appointments, yet 71% of providers say they are not trained to have these appointments with their patients. Advance Care Planning for Primary Care Practitioners can help you be prepared to offer these vital Advance Care Planning conversations with your new and existing Medicare patients. These appointments are reimbursable by Medicare B.

These courses are offered in joint providership with
National Hospice and Palliative Care Organization.

body.html:
Master’s in Health Advocacy

Students pursue an MA in Health Advocacy at Sarah Lawrence College because they want to solve problems.

Some work in and with local communities to affect change. Others help individuals navigate an increasingly complex health care system. Still others work to influence policy to make government and industry more accountable for actions that jeopardize the health of our communities.

The Health Advocacy program at Sarah Lawrence College offers:

  • An 18-month, low residency format that leads to a Master of Arts degree and prepares professionals to solve problems affecting individual and community health
  • An opportunity to work with expert faculty in a multi-disciplinary course of study
  • Experience developing a program to address your area of focus with a partner organization of your choosing
What problem do you want to solve?

body.html:
Master of Science in Dance/Movement Therapy at Sarah Lawrence College

Based on the empirically supported premise that the body and mind are interconnected and interact in health and illness, Sarah Lawrence’s Master’s in Dance/Movement Therapy program is a culmination of the College’s long tradition of engagement with the profession and with the vibrant dance community in New York City.

The Dance/Movement Therapy program:

  • Prepares graduates to take the New York State licensing examination for Creative Arts Therapists
  • Blends theoretical perspectives and practical fieldwork
  • Integrates the historical, developmental, cultural, and clinical aspects of dance's ability to heal and promote change
  • Empowers students to explore their own relationships with dance from the perspective of personal growth, reflective use of self, and social action
  • Enables students to develop and integrate their own movement abilities using their cognitive, emotional, and social resources as a means of building connections with their clients and facilitating growth and change
  • Encourages students to engage with professionals from the College’s Dance, Psychology, Child Development, Art of Teaching, and Health Advocacy programs
  • Provides a setting for ongoing research and innovation among established practitioners

body.html:
Summer Seminar for Writers
June 17 - 22, 2018


Nearly sixty adult writers converge on the beautiful Sarah Lawrence College campus for the annual Summer Seminar for Writers. Participants come from all over the United States and beyond to experience six amazing days of workshops, craft talks, generative sessions, and readings. Students choose to study along one of the following tracts: fiction, poetry, creative nonfiction, or hybrids of poetry and prose.

Workshops

The weeklong workshops are constructive, supportive environments in which students are encouraged to take risks. Workshops are capped at twelve to ensure each student has a voice as both a reader and a writer. Each workshop has its own unique atmosphere and strategies. Some will slant toward imagining the possibilities of existing work, some toward the creation of new work, while others will aim for a balance of the two. Teachers may bring in pieces of published writing to springboard into discussions of craft, structure, style, and content. In every workshop, the writing of students will be deeply considered, and participants will receive compassionate and constructive feedback.

Conferences & Generative Sessions

In addition to working with a writing teacher in class, each summer seminar student will have a 30-minute one-on-one conference with their teacher, a chance to deepen their dialogue about individual writing.

On weekday afternoons, there will be space for participants to gather and engage in a multi-genre writing exercise, directed by a teacher or visiting writer. This exposes students to different approaches and will be a space to cross-pollinate genres and to roll the creative dice.

Craft Talks & Readings

Each weekday afternoon, there will be two craft talks open to all participants in the Summer Writing Seminar. Students are encouraged to attend and hear faculty and visiting writers explore various topics. Some of these talks will be more like traditional lectures, some will be more illustrative discussions, some will be in-depth interviews. All will deepen student’s sense of the literary tradition and new ways of thinking about the art of writing.

In addition, every evening will feature a dynamic reading with two talented and acclaimed authors. To foster a dance and dialogue between genres, each reading will pair a prose writer and a poet.
